isis.stitle: ANTILOCK AIR BRAKE SYSTEM: BENDIX - TROUBLESHOOTING - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcsubproc.title: Antilock Wiring
svcsubproc.para: The antilock wire harnesses contain wires that are color-coded and have circuit numbers imprinted on them. CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS include the circuit numbers, wire colors, wire gauge and connector numbers. The connector numbers identify the various connectors by number. CONNECTOR END VIEWS displaying pin configuration and circuits that are attached for the various numbered connectors. Connectors are always viewed from the mating ends.
When diagnosing wiring in the antilock system, the following general rules apply and should be followed where applicable:

step1.para: It is generally advisable to replace a wire harness, rather than repair individual wires in the harness. If a splice repair must be made, it is important that the splice be properly soldered with a rosin flux (not acid-based) and made waterproof.

Do not pierce wire insulation when checking for continuity. Also, do not probe the EC-15 harness 12 and 14 pin connectors from the rear to check for continuity. The pins are sealed to prevent moisture from intruding. Check for power, ground or continuity only by disconnecting the connector(s) and testing the individual pins or sockets in the connector.

Always refer to the Circuit Diagram Book for wire and connector identification. Individual wire identification will differ depending upon the type of connectors in use, the vehicle model, and the system features in use.

In the troubleshooting charts and procedures, when a specific connector or circuit is referred by number, the 96/9700 model number is referred to and the corresponding number for a 93/9400 model is in parentheses. If the number is the same on both models, only one number will be stated.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing and Locating a System Problem: Self-Diagnostics
svcsubproc.para: The EC-15 contains self-test and diagnostic circuitry that continuously checks for proper operation of the entire antilock system, including wiring continuity. A yellow warning light located on the instrument panel, controlled by the EC-15, advises the driver of the condition of the entire antilock system. The condition of specific antilock components is provided to the mechanic by a series of labeled, Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) displayed through a window in the EC-15 housing.

No special tools or equipment are needed to read or interpret the EC-15 diagnostics window. It should be noted that the EC-15 diagnostics display is separate from the yellow antilock condition light on the dash. With this separation, the driver is aware that a problem has occurred, but is not confused by the diagnostic information.

A special feature of the EC-15 controller is the failure latching and diagnostic system. Intermittent problems, particularly in the wheel speed sensing area can be difficult to diagnose. When the controller senses an erroneous condition, whether in the controller electronics, the modulator or wheel speed sensing areas, it stores the condition in non-volatile memory, disables the antilock function, illuminates the dash mounted antilock condition light and the appropriate diagnostic LEDs on the EC-15.

The failure condition is truly stored and is not cleared by loss of power to the EC-15. The LEDs will re-light when power is restored and remain illuminated until the failure is corrected. After the actual problem is corrected, maintenance personnel can clear or reset the EC-15 diagnostics by passing a small magnet over the RESET point in the diagnostics window.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing and Locating a System Problem: Locating A System Defect
svcsubproc.para: ALL TROUBLESHOOTING BEGINS BY OBSERVING THE YELLOW ANTILOCK WARNING LIGHT!

While the yellow antilock warning light on the instrument panel indicates a system defect, and the EC-15 diagnostic display locates a specific problem area, it is still necessary to confirm whether the problem resides in the component itself, or the wiring or in a faulty or mis-adjusted chassis component. Test procedures (or flow charts) are provided to interpret the dash light self test, and the condition of the LEDs.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing and Locating a System Problem: Troubleshooting Procedures And Flow Charts
svcsubproc.para: Troubleshooting Procedures and Flow Charts are included in this section for each test. The Troubleshooting Procedure and the Flow Chart for a test follow the same logic, but the procedure contains some additional information. The Flow Chart offers a visual path that may be helpful. Troubleshooting always begins with Diagnosing The Initial Start-up Procedure if the "Initial Start-up Procedure" that the EC-15 performs each time the key is turned ON indicates a system defect. This procedure will direct you to the next test procedure (or flow chart) based on performance of the Dash Light AND EC-15 LEDs.

Refer to CIRCUIT DIAGRAMS while performing the tests. Also refer to COMPONENT LOCATIONS for specific locations for various components and connectors. CONNECTOR COMPOSITES are also included for each multiple connector.

It must be stressed that ALL TROUBLESHOOTING BEGINS BY OBSERVING THE YELLOW ANTILOCK WARNING LIGHT located on the instrument panel. All troubleshooting should begin by first performing the Initial Start-up Procedure and following the directions contained in it. The troubleshooting procedure DIAGNOSING THE "INITIAL START-UP PROCEDURE" is devoted to narrowing the problem to either the wiring or a specific antilock component.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing and Locating a System Problem: Important - Troubleshooting Tips

step1.para: Record all findings and the action taken on a TROUBLESHOOTING RECORD SHEET. The Troubleshooting sheet should be filed in the vehicle maintenance folder for future reference and comparison.

No voltage or resistance tests are performed into the EC-15. All voltage and resistance tests are performed by beginning at the vehicle antilock wire harness(s) side of the EC-15 pigtail connectors and moving AWAY from the EC-15 toward an antilock system component (Modulator, Wheel Speed Sensor, etc.) NO tests are performed "into" the EC-15 controller.

In the troubleshooting flow charts and procedures, when a specific connector or circuit is referred by number, the 96/9700 model connector or circuit number is used, and the corresponding number for a 93/9400 model follows in parentheses. If the number is the same on both models, only one number will be stated.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs
svcsubproc.para: There are nine LEDs, plus a magnetically actuated reset switch in the EC-15 diagnostic window ( Figure 14). The first five LEDs locate a problem to a specific area of the vehicle, while the last four indicate the problem component or its wiring. The LEDs are software driven and are either ON or OFF depending upon their monitor function.

note.para: Right and left, front and rear are determined from the driver's seat. Left front is therefore the corner closest to the driver.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "FRONT" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate the location of a problem component or its wiring. This LED (when illuminated) indicates a defect occurred in either the right or left front modulator or sensor circuits. The defect may be either the wiring or components. The FRONT LED illuminates at the same time as either the RIGHT or LEFT LED and either the MOD or SENS LED.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "MID" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED is not used in troubleshooting the EC-15 and should only illuminate when a magnet is held on the RESET switch.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "REAR" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate the location of a problem component or its wiring. This LED (when illuminated) indicates a defect occurred in either the right or left rear modulator or sensor circuits. The defect may be either the wiring or components. The REAR LED illuminates at the same time as either the RIGHT or LEFT LED and either the MOD or SENS LED.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "RIGHT" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate the location of a problem component or its wiring. This LED (when illuminated) indicates a defect occurred on a right side (passenger) of the vehicle. The defect is in either the modulator or sensor circuits. The defect may be either wiring or the components. The RIGHT LED illuminates at the same time as either the FRONT or REAR LED and either the MOD or SENS LED.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "LEFT" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate the location of a problem component or its wiring. This LED (when illuminated) indicates a defect occurred on a left side (driver side) of the vehicle. The defect is in either the modulator or sensor circuits. The defect may be either wiring or the components. The LEFT LED illuminates at the same time as either the FRONT or REAR LED and either the MOD or SENS LED.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "MOD" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate a permanent or intermittent open or short circuit in the solenoids of one of the four modulators or the wiring connecting a modulator to the system. When this LED is illuminated, either the RIGHT OR LEFT LED and either the FRONT OR REAR LED will also be illuminated to identify the defect location.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "SENS" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED illuminates and latches ON to indicate permanent or intermittent failure. The failures indicated are: open or shorted wheel speed sensor, open or shorted wheel speed sensor wiring, wheel speed signal not present or does not conform to design criteria. When this LED is illuminated, either the RIGHT OR LEFT LED and either the FRONT OR REAR LED will also be illuminated to identify the defect location.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "ECU" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Red LED, when illuminated, indicates that the controller itself has failed. It is latched ON for all EC-15 failures, except low voltage. For voltages less than 9V DC, this LED illuminates to indicate the controller is inoperative; however, when the voltage again exceeds 9V DC, the LED will TURN OFF by itself.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "VOLT" LED
svcsubproc.para: This Green LED illuminates and remains ON during vehicle operation to indicate that vehicle power is reaching the controller. If vehicle power is out of range for proper operation (below 11 vdc or above 17 vdc) this LED will flash until power returns to the proper operating range.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnostic LEDs: "RESET"
svcsubproc.para: Beneath the RESET area of the window display is a magnetically sensitive switch that is used to reset the diagnostic system. The device will respond to a magnet (magnet strength must be capable of picking up 3 ounces). With the vehicle key ON, holding a magnet against the RESET will cause all LEDs to illuminate as long as the magnet is held against it. Resetting can only be done with the key ON.
